sections.title: Introduction to Image Formation for Spherical Lenses
sections.content: Overview of image formation using convex and concave lenses.

subsections.subtitle: Light Ray Rules for Spherical Lenses
points: Similar to spherical mirrors, we use light ray rules to draw ray diagrams and determine the image formed by spherical lenses.
Ray diagrams are essential for understanding image formation.

key_terms.definition: Lenses with curved surfaces, either convex or concave.
A diagram that traces the path of light rays to determine the position and properties of an image.

examples: Using a pencil and lenses to visualize image formation.
Standing in front of a lens to see how the image changes based on position.

sections.title: Convex Lens: Image Formation
sections.content: Detailed explanation of image formation using a convex (converging) lens.

subsections.subtitle: Drawing a Convex Lens Accurately
points: Draw the principal axis (horizontal line).
Mark the optical center (O) at the center of the line.
Mark F1 and 2F1 to the left of O and F2 and 2F2 to the right of O. The distance from O to F1, F1 to 2F1, O to F2, and F2 to 2F2 should all be equal.
Sketch the convex lens, ensuring it's thin and symmetrical.

subsections.subtitle: Rules for Image Formation (Convex Lens)
points: Rule 1: A ray of light parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, passes through the focus on the other side of the lens (F2).
Rule 2: A ray of light passing through the optical center (O) goes straight, undeviated.
Rule 3: A ray of light passing through the focus (F1), after refraction, becomes parallel to the principal axis.

subsections.subtitle: Image Properties
points: The image can be real/inverted or virtual/upright.
The image can be magnified, diminished, or the same size as the object.
The position of the image depends on the object's position relative to the lens.

subsections.subtitle: Case 1: Object Beyond 2F1
points: Image is real and inverted.
Image is diminished.
Image is formed between F2 and 2F2.

subsections.subtitle: Case 2: Object at 2F1
points: Image is real and inverted.
Image is the same size as the object.
Image is formed at 2F2.
Exam tip: Draw the image first to ensure accuracy.

subsections.subtitle: Case 3: Object Between F1 and 2F1
points: Image is real and inverted.
Image is magnified.
Image is formed beyond 2F2.

subsections.subtitle: Case 4: Object at F1
points: Refracted rays are parallel.
Image is formed at infinity.
Image is real and inverted.
Image is highly magnified.

subsections.subtitle: Case 5: Object Between O and F1
points: Image is virtual and upright.
Image is magnified.
Image is formed behind the object.

key_terms.definition: A lens that is thicker in the middle than at the edges, causing light rays to converge.
Another term for a convex lens, referring to its effect on light rays.
The horizontal line passing through the center of the lens.
The center point of the lens where light rays pass through without deviation.
The point where parallel light rays converge after passing through the lens (or appear to diverge from).
An image formed by the actual intersection of light rays; can be projected onto a screen.
An image that is upside down compared to the object.
An image formed by the apparent intersection of light rays; cannot be projected onto a screen.
An image that is oriented in the same direction as the object.
An image that is larger than the object.
An image that is smaller than the object.

examples: Using a convex lens as a magnifying glass (Sherlock Holmes).
The various positions of the object and how the image changes.

sections.title: Concave Lens: Image Formation
sections.content: Detailed explanation of image formation using a concave (diverging) lens.

subsections.subtitle: Drawing a Concave Lens Accurately
points: Draw the principal axis.
Mark the optical center (O).
Mark F1 and 2F1 to the right of O and F2 and 2F2 to the left of O, ensuring equal distances.
Sketch the concave lens, making sure it's thin.

subsections.subtitle: Rules for Image Formation (Concave Lens)
points: Rule 1: A ray of light parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, appears to be coming from the focus (F2).
Rule 2: A ray of light passing through the optical center (O) goes straight, undeviated.
Rule 3: A ray of light going towards the focus (F1), after refraction, becomes parallel to the principal axis.

subsections.subtitle: Image Properties (Concave Lens)
points: Image is always virtual and upright.
Image is always diminished.
Image is always formed between the object and the lens.

key_terms.definition: A lens that is thinner in the middle than at the edges, causing light rays to diverge.
Another term for a concave lens, referring to its effect on light rays.

examples: Object placed at different distances always creates similar image.
